Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Comparative Investigation of Incipient Sex Chromosome Evolution in the genus Asparagus
Award.AbstractNarration: While distinctive sex chromosomes are a conspicuous feature of the nuclei of diverse<br/>organisms, the evolutionary processes responsible for the origins of separate genders<br/>and sex chromosomes in animals, plants and fungi remain largely unknown. The<br/>independent origin of separate sexes (that is, male individuals and female individuals) in<br/>many flowering plant lineages provides biologists with an opportunity to investigate<br/>various stages in the evolution of gender determination and sex chromosomes. For<br/>example, separate sexes have evolved within the last two million years in the genus<br/>Asparagus and the genes responsible for gender determination have been mapped to a<br/>relatively small region on otherwise recombining chromosomes. PIs, Leebens-Mack<br/>and Pires will sequence across the newly evolving female (proto-X) and male (proto-Y)<br/>forms of this region in garden asparagus in order to test hypotheses concerning the<br/>early evolution of incipient sex chromosomes and to identify candidate genes that may<br/>be responsible for gender determination.<br/>By investigating the mechanisms that promote repression of recombination between<br/>genes influencing male and female function in flowering plants, the results from this<br/>project will have implications for crop improvement and the fundamental processes that<br/>shape genome structure. Undergraduate students will also be trained in genome<br/>annotation and comparative genomics.
